title: Pencil cases needed for NZ hols
text:
Gabby Malpas designing colouring-in prints for Tourism New Zealand. Source: Supplied 
EXCLUSIVE 
THE international embrace of adult colouring-in is being used by New Zealand to try to lure Aussie travellers across the ditch. 
The country’s tourism authority has commissioned artist Gabby Malpas to prepare detailed sketches of New Zealand destinations for visitors to download and colour in . 
Tourism NZ general manager Tony Saunders said the idea was inspired by the popularity of adult colouring in books which have shot to the top of the Amazon.com bestsellers’ list. NZ artist Gabby Malpas creating colouring-in sketches for new tourism campaign. Source: Supplied 
“It’s exciting to offer people a new way to experience New Zealand, especially as we’re the first National Tourism Board in the world to showcase our landscapes through colouring in,” said Mr Saunders. 
“The sketches allow adults to unleash their creativity while planning their next adventure to New Zealand.” Stacey Bartlett shopping for adult colouring books in Alice Springs. Source: News Corp Australia 
The North and South Island images reflected in the sketches include Waiheke Island, the Hobbiton Movie Set in Matamata, Milford Sound and Cathedral Cove. 
Ms Malpas said it was a privilege to recreate such “stunning landscapes”. 
“The trend of adult colouring-in is taking the world by storm and I love that it encourages people to get back in touch with their artistic side while finding calmness along the way,” she said. 
“As people colour in the lines, I hope they will be inspired by the North and South Island’s beauty.” Mitre Peak, Milford Sound, South Island, New Zealand. Source: Supplied 
Tourism marketing expert Dr Deborah Edwards from the University of Technology Sydney , said the most successful marketing campaigns promoted a “must see”. 
“If you want to attract visitors you have to clearly articulate what the must see is,” said Dr Edwards. 
“If you do not sell what is your must see, then people won’t know why they want to go there.” 
Australian Bureau of Statistics’ data shows New Zealand remains Australians’ favourite travel destination but it is expected to be overtaken by Bali in the coming year. 
Since 2004-05, the number of Australians visiting New Zealand increased 48.7 per cent to 1.2 million. 
In the same period, visitors to Bali grew 223 per cent to 1.1 million, and travel to the US by Australians increased 147.5 per cent (to 980,000).
